titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Photographic Memory student projects RL.11657
titlestmt.author: Paula Jeannet

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-11-01 16:16:54 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Seven creative projects produced by students in Photographic Memory: Photo Albums, Photobooks, & Zines, taught by Lisa McCarty in Spring 2016 at Duke University. The one zine and six photobooks utilize photographs and ephemera from their personal archives, and document representations of women in art; a morning walk in Durham, N.C.; Duke students at a horse race in South Carolina; the Pan Mass bicycle charity event in Massachusetts; the rapid changes in downtown Durham, N.C.; a ferry service in Hong Kong; and U.S. war memorials. Through their work, the students explored aspects of the interplay of text and image, methods for sequential storytelling, basic layout and design techniques, as well as methods for production and distribution. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by student last name.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Images may only be used for educational, non-commercial purposes; any other use requires the photographer's permission.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Photographic Memory student projects were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2018.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Photobooks and zine have a variety of gatherings and bindings, including hardback and paperback, looseleaf album, hand-sewn, and folded. Printing techniques are also varied, and include true photographs, mounted on paper; inkjet prints; and offset lithography.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Photographic Memory student projects, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed and encoded by Paula Jeannet, August 2018.
Accession(s) represented in this collection guide: 2018-0084.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Seven creative projects produced by students in Photographic Memory: Photo Albums, Photobooks, & Zines, taught by Lisa McCarty in the Spring of 2016 at Duke University. The course codes were DOCST 361S-01/761S-01, VMS 361S, and ARTVIS 361S.

Students produced their own unique zine and photobooks utilizing photographs and ephemera from their personal archives. Through their work, the students explored aspects of the interplay of text and image, methods for sequential storytelling, basic layout and design techniques, as well as methods for production and distribution.
Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Affiliated with the Duke University Center for Documentary Studies, the course, Photographic Memory: Photo Albums, Photobooks, & Zines, was taught by Lisa McCarty in Spring 2016. It examined the history and uses of photo albums, zines, and self-published photobooks as a means to memorialize and document underrepresented communities, cultural movements, customs, and personal experiences.

did.unittitle: Bashaw, Halle. Durham: A city of multiple personalities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photobook documents neighborhoods and everyday life in a rapidly changing downtown Durham. Photographs are in color.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photobook documents regional war memorials and the artist's attempts to understand their meaning as a retired soldier and war veteran. Photographs are in color.

did.unittitle: Di Napoli, Caroline. Closer by the mile

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photobook documents the PanMass Challenge, a 2-day long 192-mile bike ride across the state of Massachusetts which the artist and her family participates in annually. Photographs are in color.

did.unittitle: Larkin, Rian. Bump issue #1: the femme-fatales of the fin de siÃ¨cle

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Zine issue explores the representation of women in art at the end of the 19th century and the legacy of those representations. Illustrations and text in black-and-white.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Color images in this photobook document the artist's daily walking practice in Durham, North Carolina's natural areas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Color photobook documents the revelry of Duke students at the Carolina Cup, an annual horse race held in Camden, South Carolina.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photobook documents the ferry route that tens of thousands of people take every day to commute from the mainland Chinese city of Kowloon to Hong Kong. Photographs are mounted to tissue leaves printed with Chinese characters.
